episodes.title: Exclusive Interview: W5’s Avery Haines take on alleged cult leaders of Twin Flames Universe
episodes.description:
Worldwide Exclusive Interview: Alleged cult leaders of Twin Flames Universe, Canadian Shaleia Divine and her husband Jeff Divine, face W5’s Avery Haines to respond to allegations of abusing followers, brainwashing, forced labour, tax evasion, running a pyramid scheme and coercing members into changing their gender. 

Saturday, Mar. 22, 2025 | Watch the full two-hour special edition of We're Not a Cult: Inside Twin Flames Universe |@OfficialW5 + https://www.ctvnews.ca/  

W5’s Avery Haines takes you deep inside the Twin Flames Universe with unprecedented access to their inner circle and followers as she uncovers potential evidence of abuse, fraud and coercive control.  

Jeff and Shaleia Divine call themselves spiritual gurus, but former members call them grifters who are destroying people’s lives.  You’ll hear from some of them firsthand who say Twin Flames Universe needs to be stopped before somebody gets seriously hurt.

Subscribe to W5 to watch more videos: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCPTDmZEOrQKHT-6AM7aTTTA

episodes.title: W5: Controversial religious sect in small-town Ontario preaches disruption
episodes.description:
W5 investigates a controversial Christian sect that has divided the small town of Aylmer, Ont. The Church of God Restoration and its fervent pastor have made headlines for their "anti-lockdown" rhetoric, causing turmoil in the once-sleepy town.

episodes.title: W5: Sex abuse accusations within the Jehovah's Witnesses
episodes.description:
A religious sect's doctrine protects accused sex offenders and makes it virtually impossible for complaints to be reported to police.  W5's Avery Haines investigates an alleged sex abuse cover-up within the Jehovah's Witnesses.

episodes.title: W5 RARE: INVESTIGATING SCIENTOLOGY in 1973
episodes.description:
W5 looked into allegations against the controversial Church of Scientology that had just been established in Toronto. In the US it was already under investigation for records about its founder, L. Ron Hubbard. Ten years after this profile, the Toronto offices of Scientology were raided in an investigation which eventually led to the conviction of a handful of Church members for a 'Breach of Public Trust'.
